channel.title: BBC News - Technology

item.title: What3words: 'Life-saving app' divides opinion
item.description: .Parse First responders have been singing the praises of what3words but some have reservations about the tech.

item.title: Facebook suspends tens of thousands of apps
item.description: The move comes as part of a review launched in the wake of the Cambridge Analytica scandal.

item.title: Microsoft president: Don't move fast and break things
item.description: Microsoft's president urges other tech firms to accept responsibility for the effects of their work.

item.title: YouTube stars rattled by verification changes
item.description: YouTube will remove the "verified" status from many video-makers' channels.

item.title: Huawei Mate 30 phones launch without Google apps
item.description: Handsets will offer Facebook's apps via Huawei's own store but are not pre-loaded with Google's.

item.title: Tech entrepreneurs call for more government regulation
item.description: Tech insiders say we cannot trust companies like Google and Facebook to regulate themselves.

item.title: Hackers get chance to target US satellite
item.description: The US Air Force will allow selected hackers try and take over an orbiting satellite.

item.title: Amazon's Jeff Bezos promises climate-change action
item.description: The chief executive says Amazon will buy thousands of electric vehicles and become carbon neutral by 2040.

item.title: Fish waste-based alternative to plastic wins Dyson Award
item.description: MarinaTex is an alternative to the single-use plastics such as those used in sandwich packets.

item.title: Huawei: Microsoft president seeks end to US tech ban
item.description: The US company's president warns of a "digital iron curtain down the Pacific Ocean".

item.title: Robotic fish to scare invasive species and other news
item.description: BBC Click's Lara Lewington looks at some of the week's best technology stories.

item.title: The robot that cleans floors and tells jokes
item.description: More than 100 fully autonomous cleaning robots are coming to Singapore this year, made by local manufacturer Lionsbot. Ella's job is cleaning the floors at the National Gallery.

item.title: The debate over facial recognition technology
item.description: Some MPs have called for UK police and companies to stop using live facial recognition for public surveillance.

item.title: Rebellion's Sniper Elite VR game previewed
item.description: BBC Click's Marc Cieslak plays a demo of the latest version of the World War II sniping simulator.

item.title: How bacteria could make fashion more eco-friendly
item.description: A new process to dye clothes using bacteria could bring environmental benefits.

item.title: Colour-changing ink allows objects to swap designs
item.description: BBC Click's Nick Kwek looks at some of the week's best technology stories.

item.title: The work experience you can do in your pyjamas
item.description: Big companies are offering internships via the internet, but are they a valuable experience?

item.title: The cheat hackers 'ruining' gaming for others
item.description: The use of cheats is a major problem in video games and it’s becoming increasingly lucrative as esports take off. We meet a teenage hacker’s making thousands.

item.title: Pokemon: 'Ash Ketchum failing for 22 years taught me being a loser is OK'
item.description: The world's most popular Pokemon trainer, Ash Ketchum, achieves the goal he set for himself in 1997.

item.title: Tech-savvy stamp collectors energise an old hobby
item.description: Technology is helping stamp collectors to share their passion and keep rogue operators at bay.

item.title: Algeria protests: how disinformation spread on social media
item.description: How social media became an information battleground for anti-government protesters and Algeria's rulers.

item.title: The former soldier who aims to build a $50bn firm
item.description: Shachar Bialick says his special forces background drives his success in business.
